title.narrative: Local Governments For Sustainable Urban Development (Umbrella Project) Phase Ii 2016-2019

description.narrative:
The project objectiveis to contribute to sustainable urban development and local democracy through capable, resourceful and empowered local governments. The strategic result is that local governments will have better governance structures, mechanisms and resources to fulfill responsibilities and influenceurbandevelopment agendas atall levels of interventions.
Strong and capable institutions are critical for sustainable urban development. Improved governance processes are at the core of sustainable management and planning of cities and towns. Laws and policies have to be adapted to the local needs. UN-Habitat is working through this project to develop and reinforce a conducive and enabling environment, which requires adequate legal frameworks, political, managerial and administrative process, mechanisms, guidelines and tools to respond to the needs of the population and its local representatives. While significant results have been achieved by phase I, more work is required for gains made to be consolidated and extended. This project will keep on assisting in a catalytic manner in advancing UN-Habitat's urban governance agenda and its norms, namely sustainability, subsidiarity, equity, efficiency, transparency, accountability, civic engagement and citizenship.
In order to keep contributing to the implementation of the Strategic Plan 2014-2019, the LGDU identified the need to broaden its relationships with local and regional governments and its associations as wells as with other strategic partners at normative and operational levels to raise awareness on UN-Habitat mandate in relation to urban governance and management; to develop, test, evaluate and disseminate tools, methodologies and knowledge to reinforce local governments' recognition and capacities on urban governance and management issues and to provide technical assistance to national, regional and local authorities and other institutions responsible for urban governance issues in the formulation, development and implementation of global processes such as the 2030 International Development Agenda. This project will allow the coordination of on-going efforts in the area of urban governance throughout the Agency and will leverage resources with other ongoing projects. This project builds on existing work streams within the area of governance and looks at developing more adapted approaches and means of operationalization for local and regional governments. As this is cross-cutting issues, each area will involve cooperation with another unit of UN-Habitat and/or relevant partners able to relate to and involve local governments.
In general terms, the project will address the issues raised by implementing the following strategies:
To develop and reinforce a conducive and enabling environment, which requires adequate legal frameworks, political, managerial and administrative process, mechanisms, guidelines and tools to respond to the needs of the population and its local representatives. To assist in a catalytic manner in advancing UN-Habitat's urban governance agenda and its norms, namely sustainability, subsidiarity, equity, efficiency, transparency, accountability, civic engagement and citizenship. To partner with various stakeholders at normative and operational levels to reinforce local governments' recognition and capacities. To orientate the work at local, territorial, national and global levels.
In a more detailed way, the project will operate at the same levels of phase one: 1) municipal, 2) territorial (city-region), 3) community and 4) global, always in collaboration with the national level. Moreover, the second phase of the project will address the challenges mentioned above and will specifically focus on enhancing local governments' adequate responsibilities and functions (multi-level governance), fostering their capacity to develop and implement institutional accountability and transparency strategies for urban management, promoting innovating and SMART solutions to improve municipal finances and management and the awareness and promotion of the role of local governments in global processes. The project addresses the issues in four main working lines:
1. Developing governance multilevel and multiscale governance arrangements in order to improve policies, institutional and technical frameworks, and tools to place local governments as kingpin of Sustainable Urban Development
Local governments are placed in a network of relationships and jurisdictions. Reinforcing their role, in a decentralized framework, with a multi-sector vision and at different scales requires a strong multilevel governance approach. To be able to “do their job”, local governments need to be in constant dialogue with all the other local stakeholders. To ensure effective measures and to achieve positive results for the citizens, tax-payers and economic agents, a constant coordinated action is required. Challenges such as urban mobility, employment and environmental sanitation, among others, extend beyond the realm of local governments and cover various legal-administrative divisions in the territory, hence the need for multi-level dialogue, both horizontal and vertical. Soft governance modalities, such as inter-municipal cooperation, allowing for two or more neighboring municipalities to perform together municipal administrative tasks and deliver public services or any other governance arrangements at the territorial scale could be explored. Sound territorial management is also a way to go beyond the rural-urban divide and to address metropolitan governance.
There is a need for a common vision on the political and conceptual approach of multilevel governance and to unpack and translate this concept into practical tools for the use of local leaders. There is also a need to communicate successful strategies applied for others, to learn from other contexts either about the political process as well as its implications for public services delivery and to establish new horizontal cooperation between local governments.
Moreover, Phase I has already developed significant work to improve the understanding of decentralized governance improved trough urban governance mapping by developing and implementing the Urban Governance Survey and the corresponding Urban Governance platform involving more than 100 cities, in collaboration with LSE Cities and the UCLG Committee on Decentralization and Local Governance. Additionally, the International guidelines on decentralization and basic services were championed and mainstreamed and technical assistance and continuous support has been offered through the project to five countries (Jamaica, Solomon Islands, Cape Verde, Gambia and Uganda) in the adaptation process. Regarding metropolitan governance, the first phase of the project specifically addressed coordination and cooperation between levels of governments, as one of the key issues of adequate metropolitan arrangements and directly related to decentralized governance. Publications such as the a comprehensive study “Unpacking metropolitan governance for sustainable development” was elaborated and published, specific technical assistance was given to metropolis for tailored programs to deal with the complex management issues arising from the common provision of basic urban services by different political and administrative bodies (Brazil, Colombia) and three in-depth case studies were initiated (Bandung, South Africa and Guadalajara) in order to engage further in advisory services and developing tools for improved coordination and peer-learning services, based on partnerships with Metropolis and FMDV (Global fund for city development).
The second phase of project will keep on analyzing, developing and reviewing multilevel governance mechanisms as well as developing, consolidating and disseminating knowledge on territorial and metropolitan institutional mechanisms, as most of the outputs undertook in phase one still have an open work line to be further developed. A Global database on current models of urban governance for public dissemination, comparative policy and research analysis. For further information please refer to:http://urbangovernance.net
2. Fostering transparent and accountable local governments to improve municipal management and service provision
Corruptionis, perhaps, one of the most damaging consequences of rapid urbanization processes, especially when this happens within a context of weak institutional and governance structures. High population densities in urban areas often leads to an aggravated pressure on natural resources and on the provision of basic urban services. The supply of services, such as access to land, adequate and safe housing, clean water and sanitation, among others, is finite and scarce in some cases. This factor increases pressure on local governments, sometimes, exceeding their ability to provide services and to respond to the large and vast established demand. As a result, some sectors and services are prone to corruption, misappropriation and, worst of all, inefficiency and mismanagement. Consequently, there is a tangible effect on the quality of services, eroding public trust in the accountability and merits of local governments.
It is often perceived that local decision-makers suffer from a high risk of being captured by special interests and that, in many cases, institutions designed to hold local public officials to account are not always adequate. In this regard, there is a need to generate alternatives to change this perception. Building trust in the local public administration is essential for any further action, and that cannot be possible without improving the communication with citizens on the one hand, and without eradicating corrupt and ineffective practices, especially those affecting the provision of basic services that have a direct impact on the daily lives of citizens.
A common effort to mobilize stakeholders around a local anti-corruption agenda is critical for sharing experiences and knowledge, both as a repository for knowledge on transparency and a platform for local government to engage and dialogue with the citizen. With the pressure of quality service delivery at an affordable rate, engaging and developing transparency and accountability strategies is becoming an important tool for local governments to improve municipal management and improve service provision. This project responds to the need to enhance knowledge and skills of local governments in the field of transparency and accountability in municipal management and service delivery, to allow them fulfill their responsibilities. The development of new tools to support transparent urban management cannot ignore the enormous potential of technology. Local governments need to adapt quickly to this challenge to take the advantages offered by this new window for the participation and contribution of everyone in the city. In this sense, there is a great demand by Mayors and other public managers, regarding experiences, tools and apps developed for the use of SMART technologies in the interests of greater transparency in urban management and effective fight against corruption.
Main outputs and activities developed by the phase I of the project include the development and publication of “E-Governance and urban policy design in developing countries” to enhance and promote ICT as an instrument to increase the levels of participation of people and the accountability of public policy implementation. Additionally, the project organized and supported the participation of local governments and local governments associations in international events and networks regarding accountability and transparency in municipal management promoting the awareness and advocacy of the issue of corruption as essential for good urban governance, and on the need of new tools and innovative instruments to be created to support local governments in being more transparent and accountable.
The current second phase will focus on the need to strengthen the capacity of local governments to respond to the challenges posed by corruption in urban management by supporting the development and adoption of transparency and accountability strategies in municipal management as well as promoting and raising awareness on the positive relationship between transparency and accountability and sustainable cities. The LGDU will keep its strategic relationship with Transparency International to explore possibilities for further collaboration in fighting corruption in local governments with specific focus on urban development. Transparency International (TI) defines corruption as: “the misuse of entrusted power for private gain”. Corruption flourishes when transparency is absent. Obscure, non-transparent decision making processes create favorable conditions for corruption. The absence of transparent and prescribed regulations can give substantial discretionary power to officials as it creates an opaque environment with few ‘checks and balances' (UN-Habitat, 2013).According to TI International surveys, bribery affects more than one-in-five Africans, and disproportionally affects the poor in urban areas. The majority of Africans (58%) say that corruption has increased over 2015. The situation in the Middle East and North Africa is not much different, where the majority of people (61%) across the region think that the level of corruption has gone up over the last 12 months and the fifty million people had to pay bribes to access the basic services that they needed. Which means that nearly 1 in 3 public service users suffered from corrupted practices, according to TI. Furthermore, according to the last corruption perception Index (2016), perceived levels of corruption in the public sector for Latin America are usually high. In the overall ranking, countries like Peru (85), Colombia (94), Bolivia and Mexico (103) and Argentina (107) rank low, with Venezuela being the country in the region with more corruption perceived in the public sector ranking 161 of the 174 countries surveyed. In response, in recent years, many Latin American countries have witnessed a wave of social upheaval attacking corruption cases discovered (Example: Brazil, Guatemala, Mexico).Zinnbauer, D. (2013). Cities of Integrity: Draft Working Paper.http://unhabitat.org/books/e-governance-and-urban-policy-design-in-developing-countries3. Supporting local governments in the adaptation to the new opportunities offered by SMART technologies to improve municipal sustainability
Open data strategies, open and accessible information about the implementation of public services, local governments performance monitoring and access and follow up to the municipal finances are increasingly demanded by the citizen today. This makes clear that improving governance systems and mechanisms of accountability at the local level are essential for the establishment of strong local governments, efficient and effective municipal management and local government connected to the real demands of their citizens.
In response to the growing interest of local governments for the use of technologies to improve the management of the city, there is today an emerging market of SMART (Sustainable – Monitorable – All-inclusive – Rights-based - Transparent) urban services. The inclusion of citizens in decision-making processes and the facilitation of the appropriation of new technologies by both governments and their own citizens, have enabled the emergence of innovative and inclusive solutions for improving the different challenges municipal administration. SMART technologies are changing the day-to-day lives of people in both industrialized and developing countries, producing incredible side-effects in the local economy, but also accelerating social transformation and generating a direct in impact in the lives of the poorest.
The project addresses the increasing citizen's call for pro-poor approaches, transparency and effectiveness in public service delivery, municipal finances and management. To be able to deliver their mandate, local governments need to be sustainable both financially and institutionally. In developing countries, one of the main causes of local unsustainability is the failure of local governments to expand access to affordable services for the poor and to create the conditions for the informal economy to become formal and safe. Many citizens, especially the poor, obtain basic services (such energy or water) from informal sources, creating a vicious circle where municipalities are unable to provide services because the lack of funding, and leaving citizens with the only option of obtaining unsafe and often more expensive services from informal providers. Therefore, the informal access to services appears as the only option, making poverty a permanent situation. Providing municipal services to the poor and gradually bringing the informal to the mainstream mutually benefits all, enabling municipalities to expand their revenue base, increase public expenditure and improve access to basic services, but this is a very complex and long-term process. In this context, many municipalities are looking into the application of SMART technologies (such as mobile phones, sensors or cards) to municipal finances and management, as a tool to support revenue collection and to shorten the time in service delivery, cheapen energy costs, protect the environment, increase accountability and reduce corruption. Technologies can reduce the time-lapse between the payment of the tax and the provision of the service. Smart technologies appear to be a tool to improve public service delivery, operational efficiency and ease intergovernmental relations.
During the first phase of the project and within the Future Policy Modeling (FUPOL) research consortium, an e-participation tool was developed in Mtwapa (Kenya) in the field of slum upgrading, which has contributed to gather lessons learned on the application of ICT and mobile devices with Youth and urban poor. Furthermore, LDGU, in cooperation with FMDV (Fond Mondial pour le Development des Villes) established the Uraía Platform to respond to the local governments' needs regarding last trends in municipal management innovation, seeking innovative solutions to respond to the challenges of urbanization and build more resilient and inclusive territories. The Uraía platform has creates a space for exchange between local governments and their partners about the possibilities offered today with the introduction of SMART technologies in local public management and citizen participation. The Platform offers now services of knowledge exchange, building of capacities and development of pilot projects. The work in this area has included advocacy and learning activities with focus on the development of SMART technologies for municipal sustainability, the development of guidelines on PPP negotiations and procurement and the identification and consolidation of best practices in the area.
The second phase of this project will build up on the existing platform and work on improving the network and keep the work on best practice collection, learning advocacy activities and the development of new sets of guidelines in response to the requests presented by the partners. The development of specific tools (apps) is being considered as a next step for the platform services. Full information in wwwuraia.org
4. Advocating for the role of local and regional governments in global processes including 2030 Development Agenda.
The scenario marked by the definition of the 2030 Development Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals and the New Urban Agenda has represented an opportunity to reassess the key role of local government in achieving sustainable urban development and set as a priority facilitate and strengthen its voice in the formulation and development of these global processes. Both processes require a combination of experience collection and technical expertise displaying how and what local government can provide for the achievement of sustainable urban development. There is also a need to ensure the follow-up of these international and political processes: the outcomes of the 2030 Development Agenda and the New Urban Agendas are likely to call for stronger implication of local governments, as essential responsible for their implementation.
In 2014, during the first phase of the project, UN-Habitat, UNDP and the GTF were appointed to lead the dialogue on the implementation of the Post-2015 agenda at the local level. Local and national consultations took place in 13 countries together with a number of regional and global consultations, resulting in a strategic global coalitions of partners – LRGs, CSO, United Nations agencies, etc. The Dialogues resulted in key messages underling the importance of LRGs in promoting sustainable development and in guaranteeing social inclusion, national ownership and institutional accountability. The results showcased how the new Global Agenda could not be locally implemented without the leadership of LRGs. A final report, including recommendations and suggestions to facilitate the road ahead, was developed and shared in international events and policy discussions and presented to key decision-makers of the Post-2015 framework. This process also directly related to the campaign for an urban SDG, strongly supported by the Global Taskforce and UN-Habitat bringing together bringing Mayors, Governors and local government associations to raise their views and concerns at the UN and to create awareness on the needs of local government regarding the international development agenda. Additional effort were made for advocating the importance of local governments in global processes by means contribution to research papers, advocacy and learning activities as well as participation in several events.
Furthermore, the relevant actors involved in the previous process expressed the need to be equipped with strategies, mechanisms and capabilities to translate the key outputs of the process into substantial development plans. Therefore, the three partners capitalize on the alliance, results and platforms matured during the Dialogues on Localizing the Post-2015 Agenda in order to elaborate and develop a strategy composed by principles, tools, mechanisms and processes for localizing the SDGs.
The second phase of this project will focus on this localizing strategy that will provide support by setting advocacy arguments, enabling environment and concrete mechanisms to address common global development challenges related to SDGs implementation at the local level. It will focus on main conceptual areas (multilevel governance, local strategic planning, monitoring), that constitute the base for the local implementation of the SDGs.
The project will target primarily policy-makers at local and regional level who will be the end-beneficiaries of the project, as well as local governments associations. Citizens and urbanites will be the indirect beneficiaries of enhanced capacities (human, financial and institutional) of their local representatives.

title.narrative: Project EA 1 Strengthened multi-level and multi-scale policies, institutional and technical frameworks, and tools to place local governments as kingpin of SUD

title.narrative: Number of national and local governments, promoting and implementing appropriate policy and tools for functional local governance systems.

description.narrative: Number of national and local governments, promoting and implementing appropriate policy and tools for functional local governance systems.

baseline.value: Weak articulation between different levels of governments Few governance arrangements at the territorial scale Weak metropolitan governance in targeted developing countries

target.value: At least 8 countries with reviewed, analysed and improved governance mechanisms

title.narrative: Project EA 4 Enhanced recognition of the role of local and regional governments in the implementation of the 2030 International Development Agenda and processes related to the New Urban Agenda to ensure the local dimension of development is taken into consideration internationally.

title.narrative: Perception of local governments of an effective, democratic and legitimate partner in the implementation of international development strategies and programs.
